UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
The Missoula College (MC, formerly known as the College of Technology) of the University
of Montana (UM) provides instruction in 35 occupational and technical two-year programs in
Missoula, Montana. It was founded in 1956 and was incorporated into UM in 1994. It is
currently split into two campuses: East Campus located on South Avenue East and West
Campus located on South Avenue West, collectively referred to as the South Avenue
campuses. UM has proposed relocating MC to 1205 East Broadway (herein referred to as the
site, Figure 1-1) in Missoula to meet the long-range building needs of MC and encompass
most of the MC programs and facilities in one location (proposed project). The 7.2-acre site
at 1205 East Broadway is owned by UM and is currently developed with an Associated
Students of the University of Montana (ASUM)/Mountain Line Park n' Ride facility and MC
renewable energy program facilities (photovoltaic [PV] cells, wind turbine, and hydrogen
fueling station). A City of Missoula sanitary sewer lift station is present on the southwest
corner of the site. The site sits above the north bank of the Clark Fork River. Between the
Clark Fork River and the upper part of the site is a riparian area and a user-defined (informal)
foot path that runs adjacent to the riparian area (Figure 1-2).
The 2013 Montana Legislature approved $29 million in state funding for MC relocation and
construction; an additional $3 million would come from UM. Per the Montana
Environmental Policy Act (MEPA, Montana Code Annotated [MCA] 75-1-101 through 324),
UM must evaluate the effects on the human environment of developing the site at this
location. UM must also disclose these effects to the public in an environmental document.
Because it is unclear whether developing MC at the site would generate effects that are
significant (EQC 2013, p. 27), UM has prepared an Environmental Assessment (EA).
This document is the final EA. It was prepared after public review of a draft EA (Section
1.2) and consideration of public and agency comments received during that review.
Substantive revisions between the draft and final EA are documented in Chapter 5.

text.b: PURPOSE OF AND NEED FOR ACTION

page.text: The purpose of the action is to move most of the MC to a location where the long-range
building needs and those of MC students and faculty can be met. The permanent structures
on the South Avenue campuses are 40 years old and unsuited to the needs of current
programs. The structures, which include several temporary modular units (trailers), provide
inadequate space for student services, classrooms, conference rooms, library, student
commons, bookstore, counseling, study, and instructional laboratories and faculty offices.
For example, because of the limited and inadequate laboratory space in the existing facilities,
some laboratory classes are conducted on the UM Mountain Campus and at the Montana
Technology Enterprise Center (MonTEC) facility. The existing facilities on the South
Avenue campuses were designed as open classrooms that conformed to a long out-dated
model. With the open concept floor space, heating/cooling and lighting were designed in
ways that do not meet the MC's current function and learning needs.

UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment

In addition, the rapid growth in health programs (e.g., nursing, pharmacy, radiologic,
respiratory, and surgical technologies) and increased general education science offerings,
coupled with accreditation expectations, are driving MC to provide state-of-the-art
laboratories. UM is also being charged with expanding MC to deliver the full comprehensive
community college mission through Montana's College!NOW initiative

a.href: UM MC East Broadway Final EA.html#7

page.text: . The current
facility will not allow UM to fulfill that mission.
To better utilize the benefits of changing technology, it is essential to expand and upgrade the
facilities in the computer, culinary, electronic, and energy programs. A new building would
allow MC to fully implement its goal to be a community-focused institution that supports the
educational and workforce needs of the region. These changes would allow faculty and
students to incorporate evolving technologies in the educational process.
Over the past 15 years UM has invested resources to modify and retrofit the facility to meet
the demands of a growing college. Programs have been moved to other facilities,
laboratories have been relocated, and additional walls constructed to create new classrooms.
Additionally, temporary modular units were purchased to provide more classrooms and
faculty office space. However, these investments are inadequate to meet appropriately the
needs of the region’s students for desired programs and a quality-learning environment.
The proposed project, including Phase 1 and future phases, would include construction of a
new facility of approximately 155,500 gross square feet (long-range build out) at a site
already owned by UM that would address the above needs. The building size for Phase 1
would be 105,000 gross square feet with a footprint of 21,820 gross square feet. The East
Broadway site was identified by UM for many reasons that adhere to UM's fundamental
requirements for a relocation site. The East Broadway site meets the requirement for
proximity to the Mountain Campus, and it is expected that infrastructure costs would be
lower than other sites considered in the past (Section 2.3). The proposed site would place a
state-of-the-art facility near the east entrance to Missoula and would connect MC to
downtown Missoula and local businesses; the increased offerings of courses and programs at
times convenient for working professionals would become more practical. Its proximity to
MonTEC would encourage interactions in business
technology, energy technology, computer
technology, and other programs between MonTEC and MC faculty and students.
Transportation to and from the site would be relatively easy, given the proximity of Interstate
90 (I90)and bus routes. Adequate parking is available on site and through agreements with
neighboring landowners. Finally, relocating MC to the East Broadway site would allow UM
to fulfill its mission through the College!NOW initiative. UM estimates that the new MC
location would serve 2,500 students and employees by year 10.
http://mus.edu/2yr/CollegeNOW/
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014

text.b: AGENCIES WITH JURISDICTION AND REQUIRED PERMITS

page.text: The site currently has three driveway openings on East Broadway: two paved driveways for
the Park n' Ride facility and one unimproved access for the sewer lift station. East Broadway
is under the jurisdiction of the Montana Department of Transportation (MDT) as a state-
maintained urban highway. New driveway permits and approvals concerning the traffic
analyses and proposed mitigations would be required for MC under the current MDT System
Impact Action Criteria. A variety of permits would be required by the City of Missoula,
including building/occupancy permits and a MS4 General Permit; additionally, the City of
Missoula requires a Riparian Resource Management Plan (RRMP) and that a floodplain
elevation certificate be obtained from the City of Missoula for a building permit. The
Montana Department of Fish, Wildlife, & Parks (MFWP) and US Fish & Wildlife Service
(USFWS) have jurisdiction over the management of wildlife and fish, including special
status species (e.g., migratory birds, game species, those listed as threatened or endangered,
etc.), in the vicinity of the site.
Although not an all-inclusive list, the following state and federal laws and rules would apply
to the proposed project:
• Montana Environmental Policy Act (MCA 75-1-101 through 324)
• Montana Clean Water Act (MCA 75-5-1 through 11)
• Montana Floodplain and Floodway Management Act (MCA 76-5-1101 et seq.)
• Montana State Antiquities Act and Montana Human Remains and Burial Site
Protection Act
• National Historic Preservation Act
• Federal Endangered Species Act (ESA)
• Clean Air Act (CAA)
• Migratory Bird Treaty Act (MBTA)
There are several documents that guide transportation and development planning in the City
of Missoula and Missoula County. These guidance documents were consulted during the
development of the proposed project and as part of this EA. These documents include:
• Missoula Long Range Transportation Plan Update (MMPO 2012)
• Missoula Active Transportation Plan: An Amendment to the 2005 Missoula County
Growth Policy (MMPO 2011)
• Missoula County Growth Policy (OPG 2005a, as amended)
• Missoula City Growth Policy (OPG 2005b, as amended)
• Missoula Urban Comprehensive Plan (OPG 1998)
UM has conducted a series of public meetings since 2006 to solicit public input on several
possible locations for the new MC (Section 2.3), including the site on East Broadway. Two
public forums discussing MC location alternatives on the UM South Campus (Section 2.3)
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
and the East Broadway site were conducted on September 19 and 20, 2013. After the UM
President identified the East Broadway site as UM's preferred location, UM initiated the
MEPA process with an official scoping period that began on November 8, 2013. A scoping
open house was held on November 14. Forty-one attendees signed in at the open house. UM
issued a press release on November 12 and a legal advertisement regarding the proposed
project was published in the Missoulian newspaper on November 13 and 17. Twenty-three
responses were received during the scoping period. Table 1.5-1 summarizes the issues that
were identified during the September forums and the scoping period and UM's response
and/or location within this EA where the issue is addressed.
UM released a draft EA for public and agency review on February 6, 2014 with a two week
review period. Agency and public requests indicated that a longer review period was
desired; therefore, UM extended the draft EA review period to March 7, 2014. UM solicited
public comments during this period. Twenty-two responses were received, containing 156
unique comments. Each comment was recorded, assigned a resource topic or issue, and a
response from UM to each comment was provided. In some cases, additional information or
a revision was made to the EA in order to address the comment. The comment matrix is
provided as Appendix A. Copies of the original draft EA public responses are provided as
Appendix B.
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
Access
How will people access the East Broadway site and/or
get between the two campuses?
The site is accessed via East Broadway. To get between the
two campuses, individuals can either take a bus, drive, or
walk/bike on the East Broadway sidewalks/bike lanes and
cross the Van Buren pedestrian bridge. Further information
is in Section 3.7 and 3.9.
Access
Moving MC to East Broadway will make the commute
much longer for Bitterroot Valley residents who make
up a large part of the students at MC.
The commute for Bitterroot Valley students would be longer
if MC moved from South Avenue to East Broadway.
However, numerous bus transit options exist to assist
students coming from southwest of Missoula. Also, leaving
MC at South Avenue was dismissed as an alternative for
several reasons (Section 2.3).
Air quality
Increased traffic will contribute to decreased air
quality.
Air quality effects are discussed in Section 3.8.2.2.
Alternatives
The East Broadway site is not the correct location for
MC; other sites that are more appropriate should have
been considered.
UM considered several other locations (Section 2.3) but
because the East Broadway site met all of their site criteria
(Section 2.2) and would meet the purpose of and need for the
project (Section 1.2) it became their preferred site and the
one evaluated as the proposed action.
Alternatives
There should be a footbridge over the river from the
East Broadway site to the Mountain Campus if MC is
developed at this site to reduce both the number of
people driving between the campuses and to reduce the
walk/bike time between the two campuses.
The footbridge is an important concept and UM will pursue
it in the long term. At this time it is not critical to managing
access or traffic (Sections 2.3 and 3.7.2.2).
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
Alternatives
The vehicle parking should be reduced, bus use should
be encouraged, and a trail should be developed to
reduce the number of people driving to MC at this site.
A decrease in proposed vehicle parking would not meet the
needs of MC students or staff. Regardless, improving
walking and biking conditions, as well as continuing to
provide bus service, would encourage people not to drive to
MC. UM would improve the foot path on their property and
the City of Missoula has identified the north bank of the
river as desirable to expand the trail system (MMPO 2012).
Further information is provided in Sections 3.7 and 3.9.
Alternatives
There should be a zipline across the river.
This was not considered because it would not service enough
commuters at one time and it represents a substantial safety
concern.
Alternatives
The building should be designed with "green"
principles.
The building would be certified by the US Green Building
Council Leadership in Energy & Environmental Design
(LEED) to lower operating costs; conserve energy, water,
and other resources; and provide a healthy and safe
environment for faculty, staff, and students.
Alternatives
There should be a two-story parking structure rather
than parking lots.
The cost per parking space for a vehicle parking space in a
lot is approximately $4,000 versus $20,000 for a space in a
parking structure. This five-fold increase would be cost
prohibitive due to a lack of such funding associated with the
proposed project.
Alternatives
The building should be on the street frontage rather
than set back behind the parking.
Final site planning would be implemented after the decision
on the proposed project. Putting the parking lots adjacent to
the river would make effective stormwater management that
is protective of surface water more difficult.
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
Alternatives
There should be a roundabout installed at Van Buren/E.
Broadway intersection.
There are roundabouts planned at the I90 interchange;
however, no roundabout is planned by MDT at the Van
Buren/East Broadway intersection at this time. Constructing
a roundabout is out of UM's authority.
Alternatives
There should be covered bicycle parking.
This is part of the proposed project (Section 2.2).
Alternatives
The three site development options in the Feasibility
Study are not sufficiently different from each other as
far as environmental effects.
The three most-feasible configurations were considered in
the Feasibility Plan (StudioFORMA 2013) based on many
criteria including environmental considerations.
Alternatives
The South Campus location is better than the East
Broadway location due to avoiding so much
impermeable surface right next to the river.
The South Campus location was considered but dismissed
for the reasons provided in Section 2.3.
Cultural and historic
resources
Hellgate Canyon is sacred therefore it is not an
appropriate location for the MC.
There were no cultural resources identified on the site and
the State Historic Preservation Office (SHPO) (Section
3.12.1) did not recommend further inventory (Appendix I).
Hellgate Canyon is already extensively developed and the
proposed project would not change the character of the area
or represent unique disturbance. Further information is
provided in Section 3.12.2.2.
Cumulative effects
Other projects, such as construction at the I90
interchanges, will have cumulative effects.
Cumulative effects are evaluated under each resource section
of this document.
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
Floodplains
The three potential building locations are all too close
to the floodplain boundary, and there is not enough set
back to protect against flooding and flood related
debris.
The 100-year floodplain boundary is at or below the slope of
the site (Figure 1-2) and well below the proposed building
location. This is at least 5 feet below any of the project
components including the current finish floor elevation of
the lowest level of the building at 13 feet above the
floodplain. Additionally, the closest project components of
the building are set back 60 feet from the floodplain.
Health and safety
Bike parking should be as far west on the site as
possible to avoid bicyclists needing to cross the parking
lots.
Final site planning would be developed after the MEPA
process is concluded; all such suggestions would be
considered in final site planning.
Health and safety
A pedestrian overpass from the new Park n' Ride on the
north side of East Broadway should be considered to
reduce hazards to pedestrians trying to cross East
Broadway.
A pedestrian overpass is not being considered at this time
due to financial constraints. Mitigation related to pedestrian
safety is provided in Section 3.9.4.
Health and safety
Increased traffic will result in increased safety hazards
to both pedestrians and drivers at the Van Buren/E.
Broadway intersection and I90 ramps.
Mitigation related to pedestrian safety is provided in Section
Health and safety
Locating MC adjacent to the river would pose a water
hazard to children that accompany their parents to MC.
Children must be accompanied by their parents when they
are on the MC campus.
Health and safety
Transient individuals that travel on the foot path and
occupy the riparian area on and adjacent to the site
would endanger people accessing MC.
The UM Office of Public Safety would be responsible for
patrolling the MC campus and for responding to emergency
calls. These patrols would include the riverfront area.
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
Health and safety
Increasing traffic under the MRL overpass will make
an existing safety hazard for vehicles and bicyclists
even worse.
The area described, the East Missoula I90 interchange,
would experience 6 to 15 % of the arrival and departure
(vehicle) traffic related to MC (WGM 2014b, Abelin 2014).
Traffic through this area would increase, but the level of
service (LOS) would stay at LOS A
on East Broadway
beneath the MRL overpass (WGM 2014b).
MEPA process
A MEPA document needs to be prepared.
This EA is the MEPA document that analyzes the proposed
action of developing the MC at the East Broadway site.
MEPA process
The criteria for site selection should be included in the
MEPA document.
UM's criteria for choosing the East Broadway site as their
preferred site is provided in Section 2.2.
MEPA process
The building designs were formulated using the East
Broadway site parameters, thus would be unsuitable for
other sites. This is a pre-decisional action.
Draft planning concepts were developed to evaluate the
feasibility of constructing MC at the site. This is the UM's
preferred site so it is appropriate to develop draft plans to aid
in evaluating the full suite of potential impacts related to the
project.
MEPA process
The MEPA document must analyze all potential sites
considered by UM.
See Section 2.3 for Alternatives Considered But Dismissed.
MEPA process
The MEPA document must include NEPA
's "hard
look" doctrine.
This EA thoroughly examines the effects to resources within
the scope of this analysis.
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
MEPA process
An EIS should be completed for this proposal, not an
EA.
An EIS is only undertaken when significant effects are
expected to occur that could not or would not be mitigated.
At the time of scoping the extent of effects was unknown;
therefore, an EA was completed. If significant effects are
revealed in the EA that can't or won't be mitigated, an EIS
would be completed.
Parking
The parking will not be adequate as proposed. People
will park in the neighborhoods, so these areas should
be identified.
A parking study was conducted (WGM 2014b; Appendix G)
to determine adequate parking. Parking for MC is not
expected to occur in residential neighborhoods.
Parking
Parking should be set away from the river and
greenspace, gardens (for the culinary program),
landscaping, or decks should be used next to the river
to maintain scenic values.
Final site planning would be developed after the MEPA
process is concluded; all such suggestions would be
considered in final site planning.
Permitting
A 310 permit will be necessary.
A 310 permit would not be necessary for the project as
proposed, because no development or construction would
occur in the stream banks.
Riparian resources
The riparian area will become more attractive to river
access, which could result in damage to the riparian
area.
Mitigation related to the riparian area is provided in Sections
Riparian resources
Maximize the width of the riparian area.
The riparian area would be maintained and improved
through mitigation (Sections 3.2.2 and 3.4.4).
Socioeconomics
Taxpayer monies will be used; therefore, the Fort
Missoula site should be analyzed further.
See Section 2.3 for Alternatives Considered But Dismissed.
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
Socioeconomics
There will be a financial impact to Mountain Line as a
result of increasing service on Route 4.
Evaluating the financial effect to Mountain Line is out of
scope of this analysis. The UM transportation study
(Appendix H) does examine financial effects to Mountain
Line related to future service to UM and the City of
Missoula.
Stormwater
Parking lots should use permeable materials and
bioswales to reduce runoff.
Final site planning would be developed after the MEPA
process is concluded; all such suggestions would be
considered in final site planning.
Stormwater
Stormwater should be handled in a way that mimics
natural hydrology. There should not be discharges to
surface water.
Stormwater would mimic natural hydrology and no
additional discharges to surface water would occur (WGM
2014a; Appendix D; Section 3.5.1.2).
Traffic
The MC at this site will increase traffic, especially at
the Van Buren/E. Broadway intersection and at the I90
ramps.
A traffic study (WGM 2014b; Appendix E) and a
supplement (Abelin 2014; Appendix F) was conducted; the
results are provided in Section 3.7.
Traffic
East Broadway can't accommodate the additional
traffic that would occur in its current configuration as a
two-lane road.
A traffic study (WGM 2014b; Appendix E) and a
supplement (Abelin 2014; Appendix F) was conducted; the
results are provided in Section 3.7.
Transportation
How will ASUM and Mountain Line serve MC?
These transit services would continue; however, elements
such as frequency, alignments, bus requirements, etc. would
be determined after the results of the UM transportation
study (Appendix H) are available.
Transportation
How will Park n' Ride service change?
The Park n' Ride would move to the north side of East
Broadway or to an alternate location.
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
Visual resources
East Broadway is becoming too developed.
See related resource sections for further information (e.g.,
Section 3.7 [Traffic and Access] or Section 3.10 [Visuals]).
Water quality
The minimum buffer per the Montana Nonpoint Source
Management Plan (200 feet) would not be met, thus not
affording full protection for water quality.
Stormwater would effectively be handled so that no effect to
surface water would occur. Further, the riparian area would
be maintained (and improved with mitigations, Section
3.4.4) as well as a riparian buffer.
LOS A: Free-flow traffic with individual users virtually unaffected by the presence of others in the traffic stream.
National Environmental Policy Act
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
UM would not relocate any of the MC to the site at 1205 East Broadway. The site would
continue as a Park n' Ride facility and the renewable energy facilities would remain in their
current facilities on the site. MC would stay at the existing locations on South Avenue, and
would continue to be inadequate to serve the needs of the programs, faculty, and students. In
the future, these conditions may become even more problematic because the facility will not
support additional growth in programming, and as technological needs of the programs
expand and the student population increases.
UM would relocate most of MC to the East Broadway location. The West Campus on South
Avenue would continue to house the Industrial Technology programs, such as diesel
technology, welding, heavy equipment operation, and carpentry.
The proposed project would include two main components that would occur during Phase 1
and future phases: construction of a new building to house MC and parking (Figure 2-1). At
full build out, a 155,500 gross square foot building consisting of four above-grade stories and
a basement would be constructed on a footprint of 31,100 gross square feet. The building
size for the current Phase 1 project would be 105,000 gross square feet with a footprint of
21,820 gross square feet. The Phase 1 building would include 33 classrooms (30- to 150-seat
capacity), student support areas, interaction spaces, workshops, and offices for 60 faculty/80
adjunct faculty which would meet the long-range space needs of MC. The full build-out
would occur over several phases and construction would begin in 2014. The building would
be certified by the US Green Building Council LEED to lower operating costs; conserve
energy, water, and other resources; and provide a healthy and safe environment for faculty,
staff, and students. The building would be serviced by municipal sewer and water (including
fire suppression), natural gas, and telecommunications. The existing sewer, electricity,
water, telecommunications, and natural gas service at the site are adequate to meet the needs
of MC as proposed. There are PV panels, a wind turbine, and a hydrogen refueling station
located on the existing site that would need to be relocated. The wind turbine and PV panels
provide electricity to the MonTEC facility located on the property immediately west of the
site. The wind turbine would be kept on-site but moved to a different location, the PV panels
would be incorporated on or near the new building and the hydrogen refueling station would
be relocated across the street at the north parking area or to an alternate location (see below).

Feet
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
Runoff generated from the MC would be infiltrated on-site. Runoff would be routed to
shallow vegetated swales for bio-filtration prior to infiltration where feasible. Preventative
measures would be employed during construction activities to limit erosion and
sedimentation from runoff resulting from disturbed site areas. A Storm Water Pollution
Prevention Plan (SWPPP) would be developed and implemented in accordance with state law
to address construction period runoff and prevent the release of contaminants associated with
construction activities.
Parking (both vehicle and bicycle) for MC would be provided on the site and at MonTEC;
UM has also proposed additional parking in lots located on the north side of East Broadway
on land leased from Montana Rail Link (MRL). Based on a parking study (WGM 2014c;
Appendix D) and further transportation analysis, the parking need would be met with 260
covered bicycle parking spaces, 459 vehicle parking spaces at the site and MonTec, and 341
off-site vehicle parking spaces (including a potential Park n' Ride lot). Parking is proposed
to be phased with a total of 670 vehicle spaces included in Phase 1 and a total of 800 vehicle
spaces to be completed in Phase 2.
UM considered several alternatives to the proposed project that were dismissed from further
analysis. These alternatives, and the reason for their dismissal from further analysis, are
described below.
UM considered expanding and improving the current campuses on South Avenue to meet the
needs of MC. The South Avenue site is currently the subject of an agreement with Missoula
County Public Schools. This alternative was dismissed from further analysis because there is
not enough suitable building area remaining at these locations that could accommodate a
facility of this size with the associated parking demands. The existing buildings could not
reasonably be remodeled to be multistory due to structural constraints or expanded due to
lack of suitable buildable space. Furthermore, retrofitting the existing buildings would not
allow UM to achieve the desired LEED standards. Finally, the existing campus on South
Avenue would not help to connect the MC to the Missoula downtown.
A site within Fort Missoula was considered by UM to develop into MC. The Fort Missoula
site was determined to be an unfeasible location for the full MC campus due to site
challenges that limited adequate buildable space. These site challenges included: a) flood
plain issues, b) the old Fort Missoula dump/landfill being deemed a historically significant
part of the Fort Missoula Historic District, c) artifacts found at the old dump site during an
archaeological survey of the property, and d) the recent expansion of the Fort Missoula
Historic District which now includes UM property immediately west of the Fort.
Additionally, the Fort Missoula site presents significant costs to extend the sewer system on
South Avenue to a new facility. UM spent considerable time and expense developing a
cultural resources mitigation plan for the Fort Missoula property and avoidance of these areas
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
was the final recommendation. Finally, the Fort Missoula site would not help to connect the
MC to the Missoula downtown or area businesses.
A site within the Missoula Fairgrounds was considered by UM to develop into MC. The site
was not considered further because UM did not own any property at the Fairgrounds, and the
costs to both purchase a suitable parcel of land plus constructing the facilities would be cost
prohibitive. Finally, the Missoula County Fairgrounds site would not help to connect the MC
to the Missoula downtown.
UM's South Campus was considered as a potential site for MC. It was anticipated that the
traffic effects would be greater than the East Broadway site because they would mostly occur
in a residential neighborhood, and that the infrastructure development costs would be greater
at the South Campus site. The South Campus also did not provide as strong a connection to
the Missoula downtown or area businesses. The South Campus remains the location for
future UM expansion projects under the South Campus Master Plan.
UM considered relocating MC within the Mountain Campus. This alternative was dismissed
from further analysis because there is not a suitable building site remaining within the
Mountain Campus that could accommodate a facility of this size with the associated parking
demands.
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
This chapter describes the existing conditions and effects (also referred to as impacts) of the
project alternatives to the elements of the human environment (resources). The final
determination of significance is the responsibility of the decision maker for this proposal, the
UM President (Chapter 4, Finding). Two key factors influence the determination that an
effect is potentially significant. First, the agency must appraise the scope and magnitude of
the project. Second, the characteristics of the location where the activity would occur must
be assessed. In determining the significance of potential impacts on the quality of the human
environment, MEPA rules (EQC 2013, p. 27) require UM to consider the following criteria:
• the severity, duration, geographic extent, and frequency of occurrence of the effect;
• the probability that the effect will occur;
• growth-inducing or growth-inhibiting aspects of the effect, including the relationship
or contribution of the effect to cumulative effects;
• the quantity and quality of each environmental resource or value that would be
affected, including the uniqueness and fragility of those resources or values;
• the importance to the state and to society of each environmental resource or value that
would be affected;
• any precedent that would be set as a result of an effect of the proposed action; and
• potential conflict with local, state, or federal laws, requirements, or formal plans.
The magnitude and duration of an effect are defined in Table 3.1-1.
Quality
Beneficial
An improvement of current conditions.
Adverse
A degradation of current conditions.
Magnitude
(Intensity)
Negligible
No measurable change in current conditions.
Minor
A slight, but measurable change in current conditions.
Moderate
A noticeable, measurable change in current conditions.
Major
A large, easily measurable change in current conditions.
Duration
Temporary
Short lived (i.e., during construction).
Short term
10 years or less.
Long term
More than 10 years.
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
The existing conditions and the effects of the project alternatives are evaluated in 12 sections:
3.2 Soil and Geology
3.3 Vegetation
3.4 Riparian Areas, Floodplains, and Wetlands
3.5 Water Resources
3.6 Wildlife and Fish
3.7 Transportation and Access
3.8 Air Quality
3.9 Health and Safety
3.10 Visual Resources and Noise
3.11 Recreation
3.12 Cultural and Historic Resources
3.13 Socioeconomics
The effects to resources include direct, indirect, and cumulative effects. Cumulative effects
are the collective effects that would occur when the proposed action or alternative is
combined with other past, present, and reasonably foreseeable actions related to the proposed
action's geographic location and/or type of action.
The soils onsite originally consisted of the Grantsdale loam (Unit 44), a coarse-silty over
sandy and gravelly alluvium unit typical of stream terraces (NRCS 2013). However, a
substantial portion of the site soils have been replaced by non-native fill. Although the soil
conditions on the site would not be confirmed until a formal geotechnical investigation was
performed, the native soil at the site is likely overlain by several feet of non-native fill. The
site has historically served as an excess fill disposal site for UM construction projects, and
much of the site soils had already been replaced by fill at the time UM purchased the
property (StudioFORMA 2013). However, the fill material was generated locally and would
consist of soil similar to that of the native soil at the site (course-silty over sandy and gravelly
alluvium) and typical of the soils associated with this portion of the Missoula valley floor.
These soils are well drained and are not typified by ponding or flooding (NRCS 2013).
Approximately two-thirds of the site is currently bare, disturbed soil or vegetated with
invasive weeds (e.g., spotted knapweed [Centaurea stoebe]) that do not provide protection
from soil erosion. A portion of the site consists of a steep slope that is also disturbed soil
vegetated with weeds. This slope terminates approximately five feet from a riparian area
(Section 3.3) adjacent to the Clark Fork River. The riparian area appears to prevent sediment
from the site from entering the river in most of its length (Section 3.4; Geum 2014; Appendix
C). However, in several locations years of recreational river access has removed vegetation
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
and compacted soils. Approximately 70 feet of the river bank has been armored with
concrete and boulder rip-rap. In one location, the removal of riparian vegetation and
repeated access (bank trampling) has allowed bank erosion to occur above the rip-rap.
The current soil conditions would generally be maintained on the site. In the riparian area,
continued or increasing use of the location for recreational river access would cause further
soil compaction and exposure to erosion beyond the current condition.
A preliminary geophysical assessment performed as part of the feasibility process for the
proposed project indicated that the site soils would be suitable for the construction of the
building as proposed (StudioFORMA 2013). Excavation of the site for the building's
foundation and basement would remove fill and native soils from the site; however, these
soils are not unique to the area so this would be a negligible effect to soil resources. The
entire upper portion of the site would be developed with paved parking, landscaping, or the
site building. The slope adjacent to the riparian area would be stabilized and landscaped or
revegetated with native grasses and shrubs to prevent erosion, which would be a minor, long-
term, beneficial effect on soil resources.
The development of MC at the site may cause the location to become more popular for
recreational river access, beyond which would occur under Alternative 1. This would
accelerate further soil compaction and exposure to erosion in the riparian area and on the
stream banks, which would be a moderate, long-term, adverse effect on soils in the riparian
area. Mitigation related to this effect is provided in Section 3.2.4.
It is reasonably foreseeable that the City of Missoula may extend the City's trail system on
the north side of the Clark Fork River in the future (MMPO 2011) and incorporate the trail
on the MC site. This would cause increased use of the trail and a subsequent increased use
of the riparian area on the site for recreational river access, as well as an increased number of
people passing through on the trail. This would cause a cumulative increase in the adverse
effects to soil described in Section 3.2.2.2. Mitigation related to this effect is provided in
Section 3.2.4.
To mitigate the potential adverse effects to soils as a result of increased recreational river
access, approximately 300 feet of barrier shrubs (Wood's rose [Rosa woodsii], chokecherry
[Prunus virginiana], and hawthorn [Crataegus spp.]) would be planted between the foot path
and the riparian area in the location that is experiencing the most use (approximately the
western half of the riparian area). These species are already present in the riparian area
(Section 3.4). A silt fence and individual wildlife browse protectors would be placed and
maintained in proper operating condition for the first several years until the shrubs are
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
developed enough to provide a barrier to human entry and withstand wildlife browsing. The
main access point would be left open with signage instructing users to use this access point to
avoid further resource damage and allow natural revegetation. This would reduce the effect
of increased river access to a minor effect on soils under Alternative 2. The foot path on the
site would be improved with rock berms to encourage trail users to stay on the trail and off of
riparian vegetation. The proposed trail surface would consist of either decomposed granite or
asphalt, which is higher quality than leaving it as native soil and gravel. To further reduce
erosion, native forbs and grasses would be established throughout the riparian buffer area;
this would require intensive weed management and possible soil amendments prior to
seeding to ensure successful establishment of native species..
The site currently is occupied by paved parking and incidental developed areas for the
renewable energy program facilities; however, the majority (two-thirds) of the site is
disturbed, bare ground or infested with invasive weeds (mostly spotted knapweed). A small
patch of Siberian elm (Ulmus pumila) is present on the west end of the slope that leads down
to a riparian area adjacent to the Clark Fork River. The riparian area does contain moderate
amounts of noxious weeds including knapweed, leafy spurge (Euphorbia esula), and
houndstongue (Cynoglossum officinale); the riparian area is described further in Section 3.4.
There are no special status species known to be present on the site nor is there habitat
available to support special status species that were identified in other locations in the
Missoula valley (MNHP 2013a).
The majority of the site would remain infested with invasive weeds. There would not be any
changes to vegetation on the site. Riparian vegetation is discussed in Section 3.4.
The site would become either paved parking, landscaped areas, or developed with the
building. Landscaping would utilize water-wise and/or native grasses and shrubs to the
maximum extent possible. Invasive weeds would be removed from the site to the maximum
extent possible and would be controlled according to the same protocols currently used on
the Mountain Campus; this would meet the requirements of the County Weed Control Act
‐22‐2101 (8)(a)(i), MCA). Weed control would be selective, targeting only those species
that are non-native or noxious in order to preserve desired vegetation. Native forbs and
grasses would be established throughout the entire riparian buffer; this would require
intensive weed management and possible soil amendments prior to seeding to ensure
successful establishment of native species. A detailed planting and monitoring plan would be
developed during later project design phases that is subject to review and approval by the
City of Missoula. Complete eradication of undesired weeds is unrealistic due to the
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
proximity of the site to the Clark Fork River and pedestrian trail; however, continued weed
control by a licensed applicator would be implemented with regular visual inspections to
determine maintenance needs. This would be a major, long-term, beneficial effect on
vegetation resources. An indirect benefit would be the removal of the threat of invasive
weed spread from the site to the riparian area adjacent to the Clark Fork River.
It is reasonably foreseeable that the City of Missoula may extend the City's trail system on
the north side of the Clark Fork River in the future (MMPO 2011) and incorporate the trail
on the MC site. The management of invasive weeds on the trail outside of the MC site would
therefore fall under the jurisdiction of the City of Missoula. In conjunction with the weed
treatment by UM on the MC site this would result in a cumulative decrease in invasive weeds
in the area adjacent to the Clark Fork River along East Broadway.
There are no mitigation measures proposed related to vegetation resources (mitigation related
to riparian vegetation is provided in Section 3.4.4).
A well-developed riparian area is present at the toe of a steep slope and adjacent to the Clark
Fork River (Figure 1-2). The riparian area width varies from approximately 20 feet to over
60 feet wide. The riparian area includes patches of vegetation communities consisting of
herbaceous plants, shrubs, and sapling trees. The riparian area provides important ecological
functions including erosion control, flood water retention, habitat for terrestrial and avian
species, cover for aquatic species, and a source of organic matter that supports the river
ecosystem food web. Native plant species observed within the riparian area include black
cottonwood (Populus balsamifera), narrowleaf willow (Salix exigua), red-osier dogwood
(Cornus sericea), common chokecherry (Prunus virginiana), Wood’s rose, western
snowberry (Symphoricarpos occidentalis), and slender wheatgrass (Elymus trachycaulus).
Non-native plant species observed within the area of riparian resource include leafy spurge,
field mustard (Brassica rapa), common tansy (Tanacetum vulgare), knapweed, Japanese
smartweed (Polygonum cuspidatum), smooth brome (Bromus inermus), and houndstongue
Portions of the riparian area are in poor condition, particularly those dominated by non-native
plant types. Debris piles are also located in the smooth brome community. Other areas of
the riparian area are in fair condition because they are dominated by native vegetation and
are functioning (includes chokecherry, cottonwood, red-osier dogwood plant communities).
In several locations, years of recreational river access has removed riparian vegetation and
exposed bare soil. In one location, the removal of riparian vegetation and repeated access
(bank trampling) has allowed bank erosion to occur above the rip-rap. A foot path is present
on the north side of the riparian area that consists of an approximately 1- to 2-foot wide dirt
path that is maintained by mowing.
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
The 100-year floodplain has been determined to occur on the lower elevations of the site,
below the toe of the slope but above the riparian area (Figure 1-2). There are no wetlands on
the site (NWI 2013). The Clark Fork River located adjacent to the site is a waters of the US
(Section 3.5).
There would not be any changes in the riparian area under Alternative 1. Weeds would not
be treated in the riparian area and would continue to invade native riparian vegetation. In the
riparian area, continued or increasing use of the location for recreational river access would
cause further impacts to riparian vegetation beyond the current condition. There would not
be any effect to or as a result of the 100-year floodplain.
An RRMP (Geum 2014; Appendix C) was developed for the site per the Missoula Zoning
Ordinance Natural Resource Protection, Chapter 20.50.030C.
In order to maintain the existing condition of the riparian resource, a 40-foot wide buffer
zone is proposed upgradient of the riparian area. The buffer zone was established based on
topography and the upper limits of the 100-year flood zone (Figure 1-2). This buffer is
intended to prevent encroachment by structures into the riparian area and filter surface run-
off from surrounding upland areas. A SWPPP would be developed and implemented in
accordance with state law to address construction period runoff and prevent the release of
contaminants associated with construction activities (WGM 2014a; Appendix D). No
alterations such as grading, permanent structures, storage, landscaping, burning or cutting,
filling, or fencing would be allowed in the riparian area or its buffer zone, except for the
fencing and natural barriers proposed as mitigation in Section 3.4.4 and 3.6.4. In addition, no
vehicular access through the riparian area or buffer zone would be allowed. Access would be
limited to non-motorized use only via the trail on the MC site .
No alteration or removal of existing riparian vegetation is proposed or would be permitted
within the riparian area or its buffer. However, control of noxious weeds using chemical or
mechanical methods would be permitted in order to enhance existing native vegetation
communities (see below).
Native forbs and grasses would be established throughout the entire riparian buffer; this
would require intensive weed management and possible soil amendments prior to seeding to
ensure successful establishment of native species. A detailed planting and monitoring plan
would be developed during later project design phases that is subject to review and approval
by the City of Missoula. To maintain and/or enhance the existing integrity of the riparian
area and associated buffer zone, targeted weed control would be implemented on an as-
needed basis. Weed control would be selective, targeting only those species that are non-
native or noxious in order to preserve existing native riparian vegetation. Complete
eradication of undesired weeds is unrealistic due to the proximity of the site to the Clark Fork
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
River and foot path; however, regular visual inspections and continued weed control by a
licensed applicator would be implemented.
The development of MC at the site may cause the location to become more popular for
recreational river access, beyond that which would occur under Alternative 1. This would
accelerate further damage to the riparian area, which would be a moderate, long-term,
adverse effect. Mitigation related to this effect is provided in Section 3.4.4.
There would not be any effect to or as a result of the 100-year floodplain under Alternative 2.
The 100-year floodplain boundary is at or below the slope of the site (Figure 1-2) and well
below the proposed building location. This is at least 5 feet below any of the project
components including the current finish floor elevation of the lowest level of the building at
13 feet above the floodplain. Additionally, the closest project components of the building are
set back 60 feet from the floodplain.
No fill would be placed in the floodplain that would
reduce flood water storage.
It is reasonably foreseeable that the City of Missoula may extend the City's trail system on
the north side of the Clark Fork River in the future (MMPO 2011) and incorporate the trail
on the MC site. The management of invasive weeds on the trail outside of the MC site would
therefore fall under the jurisdiction of the City of Missoula. In conjunction with the weed
treatment by UM on the MC site this would result in a cumulative decrease in invasive weeds
in the riparian area adjacent to the Clark Fork River along East Broadway. Any future work
on the trail on the MC site other than routine mowing would require amending the RRMP.
Including the foot path in the City's developed recreational (riverfront) trail system would
result in the increased use of the trail and a subsequent increased use of the riparian area on
the site for recreational river access, as well as an increased number of people passing
through on the trail. This would cause a cumulative increase in the adverse effects to riparian
vegetation described in Section 3.4.2.2. Mitigation related to this effect is provided in
Section 3.4.4.
To mitigate the potential adverse effects to the riparian area as a result of increased
recreational river access, approximately 300 feet of barrier shrubs (e.g., Wood's rose,
chokecherry, and hawthorn) would be planted between the foot path and the riparian area in
the location that is experiencing the most use. A silt fence and individual wildlife browse
protectors would be placed and maintained in proper operating condition for the first several
years until the shrubs are developed enough to provide a barrier to human entry and
withstand wildlife browsing. The main access point would be left open with signage
instructing users to use this access point to avoid further resource damage and allow natural
revegetation. This would reduce the effect of increased river access to a minor effect on the
riparian area under Alternative 2. The foot path would be improved with either decomposed
granite or asphalt and rock berms to encourage trail users to stay on the trail and off of
riparian vegetation.
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
There are no surface water sources on the site. The Clark Fork River (Hydologic Unit Code
17010204) is adjacent to the site. The section of the Clark Fork River adjacent to the site
(MT76M001_020) is classified as B-1

a.href: UM MC East Broadway Final EA.html#29

page.text: and is listed as impaired; this section is identified as
not fully supporting its beneficial uses for drinking water, primary contact recreation, or
aquatic life. The probable sources of these impairments are agriculture, mill tailings,
industrial point source discharge, and municipal point source discharges. Total maximum
daily loads (TMDLs) have been established for chlorophyll-a, total nitrogen, organic
enrichment (sewage) biological indicators, and phosphorus; however, TMDLs have not yet
been completed for metals (CWAIC 2012). The weir for the Missoula Irrigation District
ditch is in the river adjacent to the site. Except for a 70-foot length of riprap directly above
the diversion structure, the streambank consists of natural gravel below a well-developed
riparian area (Section 3.4). The riparian area appears to prevent sediment from the site from
entering the river in most of its length (Section 3.4). In several locations, years of
recreational river access has removed riparian vegetation and exposed bare soil. In one
location, the removal of riparian vegetation and repeated access (bank trampling) has allowed
bank erosion (approximately 30 feet of bank) to occur above the rip-rap.
Groundwater at the site is present at depths ranging from 30 to 40 feet below the ground
surface based on static water levels in the existing on-site well and adjacent wells.
There would not be any change to water resources. Continued or increasing use of the
location for recreational river access would cause further exposure to stream bank erosion
beyond the current condition.
Runoff generated from the site would be infiltrated on-site. On-site infiltration would
prevent runoff associated with buildings and non-vegetated areas from discharging to the
Clark Fork River. Runoff would be routed to shallow vegetated swales for bio-filtration
prior to infiltration where feasible. Bio-filtration helps to prevent concentration, and promote
photo-degradation, of contaminants prior to infiltration. Preventative measures would be
employed during construction activities to limit erosion and sedimentation of runoff resulting
from disturbed site areas. A SWPPP would be developed and implemented in accordance
with state law to address construction period runoff and prevent the release of contaminants
Waters classified B-1 are to be maintained suitable for drinking, culinary, and food processing purposes, after
conventional treatment; bathing, swimming, and recreation; growth and propagation of salmonid fishes and
associated aquatic life, waterfowl and furbearers; and agricultural and industrial water supply.
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
associated with construction activities (WGM 2014a; Appendix D). There would be minimal
risk of effects to surface water or groundwater quality related to stormwater. All supply
water for MC would be provided by the municipal water supply.
One story of the site building would be below grade; the basement finish floor would not
come within one foot of the 100-year floodplain elevation. No fill would be placed in the
floodplain that would reduce flood water storage.
The development of MC at the site may cause the location to become more popular for
recreational river access, beyond which would occur under Alternative 1. This would
accelerate further exposure to erosion in the riparian area and on the stream banks, which
would cause increased sediment to enter the Clark Fork River. However, the potential for
increased soil erosion, when compared to the relatively small stream bank area associated
with the site and the large discharge of the Clark Fork River, would result in a negligible
effect on water quality in the Clark Fork River.
There would not be any cumulative effects to water resources.
There is no mitigation proposed related to water resources.
The upper portion of the site is highly disturbed and does not support habitat for terrestrial
wildlife other than small mammals such as deer mice (Peromyscus spp.), voles (Microtus
spp.), and potentially mountain cottontail rabbit (Sylvilagus nuttallii). Animals such as
white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus), black bear (Ursus americanus), mountain lion
(Puma concolor), red fox (Vulpes vulpes), raccoon (Procyon lotor), coyote (Canis latrans),
striped skunk (Mephitis mephitis), or other mammals may cross the site from Mount Jumbo
to the north to access the river for water and also travel along the riparian corridor. A fence
at the base of Mount Jumbo was constructed to prevent wildlife from attempting to cross I90
in Hellgate Canyon; this fence has been successful in reducing road mortality for deer, bear,
mountain lion, and other mammals. However, another result is that wildlife movement
across Hellgate Canyon is limited to areas beyond the fence. Of the remaining "open space"
locations on East Broadway, the site is one of the least favorable in terms of wildlife
movement (Jonkel pers. comm. 2013).
The riparian area on the site provides habitat for a variety of wildlife and also provides a
wildlife travel corridor along the Clark Fork River. The proximity of the site to the river
makes it within the foraging area for a variety of bird species. Great blue heron (Ardea
herodias), osprey (Pandion haliaetus), bald eagle (Haliaeetus leucocephalus), and various
waterfowl utilize the river corridor for foraging, and other species such as raptors, owls,
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
songbirds, and bats forage and rest within the riparian area. This section of the Clark Fork
River supports many fish species including westslope cutthroat trout (Oncorhynchus clarkii
lewisi), rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss), brown trout (Salmo trutta), mountain
whitefish (Prosopium williamsoni), largescale sucker (Catostomus macrocheilus), northern
pikeminnow (Ptychocheilus oregonensis), and more rarely, bull trout (Salvelinus
confluentus) (MFISH 2013).
Special status species are those that are considered threatened, endangered, candidate, or
proposed for listing on the ESA, those that are listed as sensitive by a state or federal agency,
or species that are otherwise covered by a regulation such as the Migratory Bird Treaty Act
(MBTA). Table 3.6-1 provides a summary of the special status species that have been
documented within 1 mile of the site (MNHP 2013a) and their potential to occur at the site.

There would not be any effects to wildlife and fish under Alternative 1. The current habitat
conditions would continue, but in the riparian area continued or increasing use of the location
for recreational river access would cause impacts to riparian habitat beyond the current
condition.
The site would be developed as proposed, which would remove habitat used by animals
where the building foundation was excavated. There would not be any effect to wildlife that
cross the site to access the river; these animals would likely continue to cross the site during
night-time hours when human activity (and traffic) is at its lowest. There would be
moderate, long-term, adverse effects to wildlife, particularly bears, related to litter attractants.
This would result in the increased chance of wildlife habituation to consuming litter and
increase the chance for wildlife-human interactions. Mitigation related to this effect is
provided in Section 3.6.4.
Moderate, adverse, long-term effects could occur to songbirds (particularly during migration)
and smaller species of hawks and owls from the potential to strike the glass windows of the
building. This effect would be lessened through mitigation to reduce bird mortality (Section
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
An improvement in habitat would be made on the slope adjacent to the riparian area (within
the riparian buffer, Section 3.4); this slope would be rehabilitated and revegetated with native
grasses and shrubs which would extend the valuable habitat present in the current riparian
area. The development of MC at the site may cause the location to become more popular for
recreational river access, beyond which would occur under Alternative 1. This would
accelerate further damage to the riparian habitat, which would reduce the amount of habitat
and forage available for wildlife. This would be a negligible to minor, long-term, adverse
effect because adequate suitable habitat for wildlife is available elsewhere along the riparian
corridor. Effects to special status species are provided in Table 3.6-2.

It is reasonably foreseeable that the City of Missoula may extend the City's trail system on
the north side of the Clark Fork River in the future (MMPO 2011) and incorporate the trail
on the MC site. The management of invasive weeds on the trail outside of the MC site would
therefore fall under the jurisdiction of the City of Missoula. In conjunction with the weed
treatment by UM on the MC site this would result in a cumulative decrease in invasive weeds
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
in the riparian area adjacent to the Clark Fork River along East Broadway, which would
cumulatively improve riparian habitat in this area.
Including the foot path in the City's developed recreational (riverfront) trail system would
result in the increased use of the trail and a subsequent increased use of the riparian area on
the site for recreational river access. This would cause a cumulative increase in the adverse
effects to riparian habitat described in Section 3.6.6.2. Mitigation related to this effect is
provided in Section 3.4.4.
There is the potential that the litter generated and stored on the site would attract wildlife,
particularly bears. UM would install wildlife-resistant garbage receptacles and dumpsters on
the site, and would adhere to the same bear management as that used for the Mountain
Campus. This would reduce the impact of litter attractants to a negligible effect.
The potential for bird mortality due to building strikes would be reduced to a minor effect by
adding bird-friendly designs such as using non-reflective glass to the proposed building.
Such measures are recommended by the American Bird Conservancy (ABC, date unknown)
and endorsed through LEED in its green building certification guidelines.
Mitigation related to the osprey nest on the site was developed in conjunction with UM
Wildlife Biology Program faculty that oversee the nest. From approximately mid-April to
mid-May there would be a 150-foot buffer around the nest site that would be excluded from
construction activities. A fence or heavy shrub planting would be constructed around the
nest pole. Educational signage regarding the osprey nest would also be provided. These
mitigations would reduce the potential effects to nesting osprey to a negligible effect. Other
mitigations, such as moving the nest pole or extending the height of the pole, would be
considered in the future if the mitigations provided above are not successful. The success of
the proposed mitigations would be monitored by the UM Wildlife Biology Program faculty
that oversee the nest.
To mitigate the potential adverse effects to the riparian habitat as a result of increased
recreational river access, approximately 300 feet of barrier shrubs (e.g., Wood's rose,
chokecherry, and hawthorn) would be planted between the trail and the riparian area in the
location that is experiencing the most use. A silt fence and individual wildlife browse
protectors would be placed and maintained in proper operating condition for the first several
years until the shrubs are developed enough to provide a barrier to human entry and
withstand wildlife browsing. The main access point would be left open with signage
instructing users to use this access point to avoid further resource damage and allow natural
revegetation. This would reduce the effect of increased river access to a minor effect on the
riparian area under Alternative 2. The foot path would be improved with either decomposed
granite or asphalt and rock berms to encourage trail users to stay on the trail and off of
riparian vegetation. Native forbs and grasses would be established throughout the entire
riparian buffer; this would require intensive weed management and possible soil amendments
prior to seeding to ensure successful establishment of native species.
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
A Traffic Impact Study (TIS; WGM 2014b; Appendix E) was conducted to analyze the
effects of the proposed project. A supplemental analysis was conducted to address comments
received on the draft EA (Abelin 2014; Appendix F). The following intersections are
addressed in the TIS and the supplement:
th
Street and Arthur Avenue
th
Street and Arthur Avenue
• Madison Street and East Broadway
• Van Buren Street and East Broadway
• I90 eastbound ramps and Van Buren Street
• I90 westbound ramps and Van Buren Street
• I90 eastbound ramps and East Broadway (the East Missoula interchange)
• I90 westbound ramps and East Broadway
• East Broadway and the proposed site driveways
Traffic generated by MC is highest in the morning (7:00 am to 9:00 am) and during mid-day
(11:00 am to 1:00 pm). The analysis was limited to these time periods as impacts to the
afternoon peak hour were expected to be minimal. Estimated traffic generated by the
existing MC is provided in Table 3.7-1. Further detail regarding development of these values
is provided in the TIS (WGM 2014b; Appendix E).
The TIS analyzed a 10-year study period that extended to 2023. The traffic volume in 2023,
without the proposed project (or no-build), was calculated for each of the study intersections.
From these values, the current morning peak and mid-day peak traffic at intersections within
the TIS study area was assigned a level of service (LOS) category (AASHTO 2011)
(Figure 3-1) based on several traffic characteristics including how well the traffic would
flow:
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
LOS A: Free-flow traffic with individual users virtually unaffected by the presence
of others in the traffic stream.
LOS B: Stable traffic flow with a high degree of freedom to select speed and
operating conditions but with some influence from other users.
LOS C: Restricted flow that remains stable but with significant interactions with
others in the traffic stream. The general level of comfort and convenience declines
noticeably at this level.
LOS D: High-density flow in which speed and freedom to maneuver are severely
restricted and comfort and convenience have declined even though flow remains
stable.
LOS E: Unstable flow at or near capacity levels with poor levels of comfort and
convenience.
LOS F: Forced traffic flow in which the amount of traffic approaching a point
exceeds the amount that can be served. LOS F is characterized by stop-and-go
waves, poor travel times, low comfort and convenience, and increased accident
exposure.
Bus service is currently provided to the site by Mountain Line Route 4, operating on a one-
hour headway during the morning peak hour and a three-hour headway during the afternoon
peak hour. ASUM provides bus service to the site (via the Park n' ride) every 10 to 20
minutes. Mountain Line and ASUM also provide bus service to the existing MC location;
many MC students utilize bus transportation.
Designated bike lanes approach the site on both the north and south sides of East Broadway
from the Van Buren intersection to Easy Street. It is unknown if the bike lanes, while
designated as such, meet Federal Highway Administration Manual of Uniform Traffic
Control Devices (MUTCD) recommendations for signage and pavement markings; site
reconnaissance of the bike lane on the south side of East Broadway indicated that a solid
white line marking the bike lane is present along the entire length of East Broadway from
Van Buren to Easy Street on the south side but other pavement markings, such as bicycle
symbols, are infrequent when compared to those on the north side of East Broadway in the
same stretch. Very few people currently ride bicycles to the existing MC (Appendix E). A
concrete pedestrian sidewalk also is present on the south side of East Broadway from the Van
Buren intersection to Easy Street. There is no pedestrian sidewalk on the north side of East
Broadway in front of the site.
The current combined parking demand for the existing MC campus and the Park n' Ride
currently on the East Broadway site is 620 vehicles per day. This includes a peak parking
demand of 467 vehicles at the existing MC campus and 153 vehicles at the Park n' Ride. The
available parking at these two locations is a combined 755 spaces. There is no parking
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
currently on the MRL lot on the north side of East Broadway. MonTEC, located adjacent to
the site, has a peak vehicle parking demand of 32 vehicles (WGM 2014c; Appendix G).
The City of Missoula, Missoula Urban Transportation District (MUTD), UM, and ASUM
have a joint interest in improving commuter mobility and enhancing alternative
transportation modes in and around UM and between UM and downtown. These entities
have commissioned a comprehensive study that will examine the short- and long-term
transportation and parking needs associated with the Missoula campuses and surrounding
areas. Because the East Broadway site is UM's preferred site for the MC, the future
transportation needs and options associated with the East Broadway site are included in the
scope of the study (Nelson/Nygaard 2013). The study is taking into account the proposed
parking and size for the MC (StudioForma 2013). If the East Broadway site is approved by
the UM decision-maker, this study will guide transportation and parking improvements and
decisions associated with the MC.
Recommendations for bus service between the East Broadway site and the Missoula
downtown will be developed, including alignments, facilities, and frequency. UM and MC
staff, student, and faculty travel patterns will be assessed to identify potential markets for
transit, ridesharing, cycling, and walking. The study will identify gaps in the existing bicycle
and pedestrian network, in particular for connections to the proposed MC site on East
Broadway. Parking pricing structures and strategies will be identified. Finally, the analysis
of the existing and future transportation conditions will be used to formulate transportation
demand management (TDM) and parking management strategies that have potential for
improving access to the East Broadway site while at the same time optimizing how parking is
managed. The scope of work for the study (Nelson/Nygaard 2013) is included as Appendix
H.
There would be gradual increases in traffic volume as the population of Missoula grows, but
there would be no contribution to traffic in the TIS study area due to MC. Traffic at the
existing MC campus would increase from current levels as the student population grows.
The existing Park n' Ride would be maintained at the site and would likely experience
increased use in the future commensurate with growth of the UM student population and
other Missoula users.
Both ASUM and Mountain Line would continue to service the site and the existing MC
campus. There would not be any changes to biking or pedestrian travel on East Broadway in
the vicinity of the site.

Traffic associated with MC would shift from the current location in the South Avenue area to
the TIS study area. The anticipated site-generated traffic for the East Broadway MC location
was estimated and is provided in Table 3.7-2. Further detail regarding development of these
values is provided in the TIS (WGM 2013b; Appendix E).
There would be a minor (~5 %) to major (up to ~60 %) increase in traffic volume on East
Broadway during the peak hours as a result of the MC. This may create safety hazards for
people crossing East Broadway to access MC. Section 3.9.2 provides a discussion of safety
related to traffic. The traffic volume in 2023, with the proposed project (or build), was
calculated for each of the study intersections. From these values, each study intersection was
assigned the appropriate LOS under those conditions at both the morning peak and mid-day
peak traffic (Figure 3-2).
Based on the TIS, the effect to traffic and LOS on the study intersections would be negligible
to minor, with most intersections staying at the same LOS or decreasing only one level.
The LOS at the two site driveways would degrade from a current LOS A to LOS C during
the morning peak hour and to a LOS D during the mid-day peak hour. This would be a
moderate effect on traffic at these locations in the morning and a major effect in the mid-day
that would be adverse and long term. Mitigation related to this effect is provided in Section
A driveway analysis was conducted for the proposed project because East Broadway is under
MDT jurisdiction as a state-maintained urban highway. This analysis is required to obtain
new driveway permits from MDT. The analysis shows warrant for right turn lanes at both of
the proposed MC driveways on East Broadway. However, further analysis (Abelin 2014;
Appendix F) indicated that constructing a right turn lane may not be beneficial at this
location. No left turn lane is warranted for the proposed driveways to MC or the potential
parking facilities on the north side of East Broadway.

Careful planning for the parking for MC would be required for the protection of the students
and faculty. There are no safe options for overflow parking at the site should parking
demand exceed the supply. The feasibility study for the proposed project (StudioFORMA
2013) originally analyzed 730 parking spaces (vehicle and bicycle). However, further
analysis (WGM 2014c; Appendix G) has recommended MC provide 600 parking spaces and
the Park n' Ride provide 200 parking spaces for a total of 800 parking spaces. This
recommended number of spaces is based on vehicle counts of the current MC parking lots,
applying a growth factor to both the MC and the Park n' Ride, and then subtracting an
appropriate number of spaces for bus service. The Missoula Zoning Ordinance has identified
a maximum of 430 vehicle spaces that should be provided and the Institute of
Transportation’s Parking Generation, 4
th
Edition, recommends 500 total spaces. All of these
projections for needed parking are based on 2,500 students attending the MC.
The total amount of parking spaces for the MC would be constructed in two phases. WGM
(2014c) recommends 470 parking spaces for the students and faculty be available for Phase I.
WGM (2014c) indicates that these 470 spaces would be split with 430 parking spaces
constructed at the MC and sharing 40 spaces at MonTech. A more detailed analysis of the
land available on the MC site indicates that there is enough space to construct 404 parking
spaces. In addition, based on further analysis of the Montech site, there are an additional 15
spaces that can be developed. Therefore, a total of 459 parking spaces can be developed on
the south side of East Broadway. The full amount of vehicle parking between the East
Broadway site and MonTEC and about 66 percent of the offsite parking would be
constructed in Phase I, and the majority of the (covered) bicycle parking. In Phase II, the rest
of the offsite parking (both vehicle and bicycle) would be constructed (Table 3.7-3).

Bike parking
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
