The MC is proposing to construct the Park n' Ride on the north side of East Broadway from
land that would be leased from MRL or another offsite location. Because of the linear nature
of the parking proposed within the MRL right-of-way, some of the parking spaces in this area
would be located at distances in excess of 500 to 1,500 feet from the main entrance. This
may create safety hazards for people crossing East Broadway to access MC. Section 3.9.2
provides a discussion of safety related to the proposed parking.
ASUM projects that service would be provided every 10 minutes between the MC and the
Mountain Campus. There may also be improved frequency of ASUM service between the
MC, downtown, and other areas; this frequency would be refined when the transportation
study undertaken by the City of Missoula, MUTD, UM, and ASUM is concluded (Appendix
H). Mountain Line service is not projected to change.
A pedestrian sidewalk would be constructed on the north side of East Broadway that spans
the potential parking lot. There may be an increase in bicyclists and pedestrians using the
bike lanes and pedestrian sidewalks. This increase in bicyclists is unknown because few
people currently ride their bike to the existing MC campus, but there would be some
students, staff, and faculty that commute via bicycle to the MC as well as students that travel
between the Mountain Campus and the MC for classes.
There would not be any past, present, or reasonably foreseeable projects that would
cumulatively negatively affect traffic in the long term, and none that would affect parking.
MDT performed a signal timing study and associated signal timing changes in 2010-2011
that improved the LOS of the intersections studied in the TIS and the supplemental analysis.
MDT is currently preparing plans for the reconstruction of the Van Buren Street I90
interchange. The reconstruction will include two roundabouts at the interchange ramps and
is scheduled for completion in 2016. It is likely that the interchange project would be
completed prior to the opening of the new MC campus. In developing the 2023 LOS
categories for Alternative 1 (no-build) and Alternative 2 (build), the TIS and the
supplemental analysis assumed that the MDT interchange improvement project, including
roundabouts, was constructed; therefore, it would not be considered as a cumulative effect.
The 2011 Missoula Active Transportation Plan and the 2012 Long Range Transportation
Plan Update include goals to address the issues of missing bicycle travel connections, natural
barriers to bicycles, and pinch points (MMPO 2011, MMPO 2012). The UM transportation
study also includes goals to examine these issues around UM campuses (Appendix H). UM
would coordinate with MDT on all MUTCD recommended signage and pavement markings
on the bike lanes between Van Buren and the MC site prior to the MC opening (Section
Combined with the studies described above there would be a cumulative beneficial
effect on bicycling facilities in the area.
MDT has indicated that if a traffic light is warranted at the proposed site, it would allow UM
to initiate the approval process to install a traffic light with corresponding maintenance by
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
MDT

a.href: UM MC East Broadway Final EA.html#45

page.text: ; refer to Section 1.3 for a summary of MDT's jurisdictional responsibilities for East
Broadway. A traffic light warrant analysis was conducted for the proposed MC site. Due to
the proximity of the two approaches to the MC (from the east or west), the signal warrant
analysis was performed for only the eastern approach and the east driveway. This
intersection would provide additional service to the potential parking and Park n' Ride lot to
the north and would be the ideal location to provide traffic control for the MC, the north
parking, and any pedestrians crossing between these two locations. Abelin (2014) has
indicated that a traffic signal at the east driveway is warranted at full build out (2,500
students) (Appendix F). A traffic signal at this location would mitigate traffic effects by
slowing traffic and providing a signalized pedestrian crossing (Section 3.9.4). The effects to
the LOS at the site driveways would be mitigated to a negligible to minor effect; if the east
intersection were signalized it would operate at LOS B with considerable reserve capacity.
The west driveway would function at LOS C as an unsignalized intersection with 25 percent
of its left-turn traffic drawn off to the traffic signal on the east intersection (Abelin 2014;
Appendix F).
UM would coordinate with MDT on all MUTCD recommended signage and pavement
markings on the bike lanes between Van Buren and the MC site prior to the MC opening.
The Clean Air Act (CAA), regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), sets
standards for air pollutants. The EPA allows individual states to adopt and enforce their own
regulations related to air quality that are as stringent or more than the federal air quality
standards. The CAA also designated areas of the nation into Class I and Class II airsheds.
Class I airsheds are given the most protection from human-caused air pollution to protect
their pristine character; all other areas are Class II. The closest Class I airshed to the site is
the Rattlesnake Wilderness located approximately 7 miles to the northeast of the site. Areas
that violate National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQSs) are classified as
nonattainment areas. The site is located within the boundary of the Missoula nonattainment
area (particulate matter [PM]
). The primary source of PM
pollution in Missoula is road
dust, construction activities (fugitive dust), industries that produce fugitive dust, and certain
emissions from vehicles. The primary stationary source of PM
pollution in the Missoula
valley is Rosberg Forest Products located 3.5 miles west-northwest of the site.
Carbon monoxide and PM
are two other pollutants that, while not at levels designated as
nonattainment in Missoula, are a concern related to air quality. In an urban environment
such as Missoula carbon monoxide is most commonly caused by combustion from mobile
sources such as vehicles. The site is located on East Broadway, which currently receives
moderate levels of vehicle traffic. Several intersections in the TIS (WGM 2014b; Appendix
E and Appendix F) experience vehicle backup (Figure 3-1) which contributes to decreased
MDT would not be able to participate as a financial partner on the proposed mitigations at this time.
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
air quality. Intersections in the TIS within residential areas would have more sensitive
receptors than those located in commercial areas. Wildfire smoke, which commonly
accumulates in the Missoula valley in the late summer and fall when wildfires are active in
the area, does not count towards violations of the CAA but does represent a major factor
affecting Missoula's air quality during periods of extensive wildfire activity.
Missoula emissions generally disperse to the east during the day and to the west at night.
The "Hellgate winds", which come in from the northeast and occur predominantly in the
winter, strongly affect the site in its location at the mouth of Hellgate Canyon.
There would be gradual increases in traffic volume as the population of Missoula grows
(Table 3.7-3), but there would be no contribution to traffic or degradation of air quality due
to traffic in the TIS study area due to MC.
There would be negligible to minor effects to the LOS at the area intersections; therefore,
there would be a negligible to minor effect on air quality. The exception would be at the site
driveways; there would be a moderate to major effect to air quality at these locations.
Increased idling times would result in an increase in carbon monoxide and decreased air
quality, especially during peak hours. Mitigation applied to reduce the effect to negligible to
minor (Section 3.7.4) would also reduce the effect similarly to air quality.
There would not be any cumulative effects to air quality.
Mitigations related to traffic, and therefore air quality, are provided in Section 3.7.4.
Currently, there is pedestrian travel on the sidewalk on the south side of East Broadway and
bicycle travel in the designated bike lanes on both sides of East Broadway. Public comment
on the proposed project and as described in WGM (2014b) has indicated that bicyclists do
not feel comfortable crossing the Van Buren intersection, in particular from the north to turn
left on East Broadway and from the west to turn left and go south on Van Buren. Bikes
moving in these directions must leave the bike lane, cross two lanes of traffic, and enter a left
turn lane. Many bike riders are uncomfortable with this movement and the movement is less
safe because it is out of the bike lane; therefore, some bicyclists simply ride on the sidewalk
on the south side of East Broadway. The bike lane on the south side of East Broadway
leaving the Van Buren intersection is marked with a solid white line but infrequently with
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
other pavement markings such as bicycle symbols, which also does not encourage use of the
bike lane. The above factors appear to cause some bicyclists simply to ride on the sidewalk
on the south side of East Broadway. Bicyclists are also observed to ride through the parking
lot at Eastgate Shopping Center. These are not safe conditions as bikes are not as visible or
expected in parking lots. Bikes using the sidewalk creates a conflict between bikes and
pedestrians and are in violation of Missoula City Ordinance.
There would not be any effect on health and safety under Alternative 1.
Sidewalk would be constructed on the north side of East Broadway that would span the
length of the potential parking lot on MRL property, unless other offsite parking is developed
(Section 3.7.2.2). Because of the linear nature of the parking in this location, some of the
parking spaces in this area would be located at distances in excess of 500 to 1,500 feet from
the main entrance. Transit service would also drop off individuals at the potential Park n'
Ride facility or along bus stops on the north side of East Broadway. This would create safety
hazards for people crossing East Broadway to access MC, which would be a moderate,
adverse, long-term effect. Health and safety mitigation is provided in Section 3.9.4.
There is likely to be an increase in bicycle use in the corridor with the addition of MC and
the large number of covered bicycle parking spaces. Because of the conditions described in
Section 3.9.1, some bicyclists would continue to use the sidewalk rather than the bike lane, or
would choose not to bike to the MC. This would be a moderate, adverse, long-term effect.
Mitigation to reduce this effect is provided in Section 3.9.4.
The UM Office of Public Safety would be responsible for patrolling the MC campus,
including the riverfront area, and for responding to emergency calls. This office would also
provide similar services to students, such as emergency phones.
The 2011 Missoula Active Transportation Plan and the 2012 Long Range Transportation
Plan Update include goals to address the issues of missing bicycle travel connections, natural
barriers to bicycles, and pinch points (MMPO 2011, MMPO 2012). The UM transportation
study also includes goals to examine these issues around UM campuses (Appendix H).
Combined with the mitigation to provide a traffic signal crossing on East Broadway (Section
3.9.4), these studies would cumulatively improve the bicycling facilities, and therefore biking
safety, in this location.
Abelin (2014) has indicated that a traffic signal is warranted at the site's east driveway at full
build out (2,500 students); therefore, upon MDT approval of the traffic analyses and
mitigation (Section 1.3) UM would work with MDT to install a traffic signal at this location.
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
This would provide a safe crossing for individuals accessing the MC from the north bike
lane, sidewalk, or parking lot, as well as to reduce traffic speed. If a second crossing to the
west is found to be necessary during final site planning, UM would propose MDT (Section
1.3) install a rectangular rapid flashing beacon alerting motorists to the second pedestrian
crossing. In conjunction with the traffic signal there would be a high degree of visibility for
those crossing East Broadway to access MC. The transit stop would be maintained at the
existing Park n' Ride location and a transit stop would be constructed at the Park n' Ride on
the offsite parking lot to reduce the number of pedestrians crossing East Broadway. These
mitigation measures would reduce the hazards to those crossing East Broadway to a
negligible to minor effect.
Two of the goals of the transportation study being undertaken by the City of Missoula,
MUTD, UM, and ASUM (Appendix H) is to identify pedestrian and bicycle facilities, and
how they connect to one another (including paths, bike lanes, designated bike routes), and to
identify gaps in that network. These entities will then work together to provide safe and
convenient facilities for UM, MC, and other local pedestrians and bicyclists. UM would
coordinate with MDT on all MUTCD recommended signage and pavement markings on the
bike lanes between Van Buren and the MC site prior to the MC opening.
Safe and
convenient facilities would reduce safety hazards for pedestrians and bicyclists and
encourage students to ride bicycles or walk between the campuses, reducing traffic effects
while improving air quality and the health of students.
The site is located within a medium density, mixed residential, commercial, and light
industrial area. The site is visible from observation points on East Broadway, I90, Jacob's
Island, the Kim Williams Trail, Mount Jumbo, Mount Sentinel, and from the Clark Fork
River. Observers would notice the paved parking lot and the bus shelter for the Park n' Ride
on the one-third of the site adjacent to East Broadway. The renewable energy facilities are
set back from East Broadway, but the wind turbine is a noticeable feature particularly when
entering or leaving Missoula from East Broadway and I90. The remainder of the upper
portion of the site appears as barren, disturbed ground with uneven topography. The site is
noticeably more vacant than the properties adjacent to it, which are developed with modern
buildings and parking lots. A steep slope leads down to a riparian area with a foot path.
Noise receptors associated with the proposed project are individuals within 0.5 mile of the
site, including individuals passing through the area (pedestrians, river and trail users) and
those located within businesses and residences within 0.5 mile. A sensitive receptor would
be the residents and patients of the Riverside Health Center located adjacent to the site;
Riverside Health Center provides respite and long-term care for elderly individuals.
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
Currently, noise is primarily generated in the area from vehicle traffic, trains, and wind.
Trains travel regularly through the corridor on tracks located just north of East Broadway and
the locomotives sound horns in short to long blasts as they approach the Madison Street
crossing. Secondary noise sources are the site wind turbine, human voices, planes flying
overhead on route to Missoula International Airport, and occasionally (in fall) noise from the
UM Grizzly Stadium (Figure 1-1).
There would be no change from the current visual or noise conditions under Alternative 1.
The change from a relatively undeveloped site to one with a building with four stories above
grade, more parking, and landscaping would be a moderate, long-term effect to visual
resources that would be neutral, beneficial, or adverse depending on the opinion of the
observer. The change would also depend on whether the observer was familiar with the site
prior to its build-out, since the development would look consistent with the other properties
in the area. In the short term, the building would appear to be new and noticeably more
modern than other buildings near it. Observers would notice construction activity
temporarily and in the short term as new phases of the building were constructed. The most
noticeable changes would be by observers familiar with entering or leaving Missoula from
via East Broadway and I90. The building would be the tallest building in one's view as one
entered Missoula until the four-story motel located 0.25 mile from the site was encountered.
The parking lots across East Broadway (on land leased from MRL) would be a major, long-
term effect that would be neutral, beneficial, or adverse depending on the opinion of the
observer. This land is currently disturbed but vacant. Observers familiar with the land
would notice the paved parking lots and rows of parked cars. Observers unfamiliar with the
land would not notice a feature that differs from the surrounding environment, since parking
lots are common on both sides of East Broadway.
The slope to the riparian area would be rehabilitated and revegetated with native grasses and
shrubs, which would be a long-term, moderate, beneficial visual effect to individuals
traveling on the trail. The riverscape would be incorporated into the MC design through
signage and other landscaping features (outside of the riparian area).
There would be a minor, temporary, increase in noise related to construction activities for
MC. Because MC would be built out in phases, each time a new phase was constructed there
would be similar temporary noise increases. Construction noise would only be generated
during the day (approximately 8:00 am to 5:00 pm). The greatest construction noise source
would be backup alarms on large equipment.
UM MC East Broadway Site
Final Environmental Assessment
May 2014
Long term, there would be minor changes in traffic noise. MC staff and students would be
most likely to notice train noise when they are in the parking lots. Inside the building and in
open spaces behind the building the train noise would be less noticeable but would be heard.
This effect would lessen with time as staff and students grew accustomed to this background
noise (similar to vehicle traffic).
The implementation of the proposed project would cumulatively add to East Broadway's
developed, urban aesthetic. This would be a small cumulative effect, because the site
improvements already appeared commercial or light industrial in nature.
There would be short-term cumulative increases in construction noise during MDT's
reconstruction of the I90-Van Buren interchange.
To mitigate the effect of construction noise on nesting osprey, from approximately mid-April
to mid-May there would be a 150-foot buffer around the nest site that would be excluded
from construction activities.
The Clark Fork River is popular for rafting, tubing, fishing, paddleboarding, and other
recreational activities. There is a popular informal river access point on the site that receives
moderate to heavy use during the summer months. A footpath adjacent to the riparian area is
used to access the river but is also used throughout the year by residents of the area.
Additionally, an unimproved road used by the City of Missoula to access the sewer lift
station from East Broadway is also used for river access (non-motorized access only).
There would be continued or increased pedestrian use of the river access point and the
unimproved road on the site in conjunction with a general increase in river recreation in
Missoula.
The development of MC at the site may cause the location to become more popular for
recreational river access, beyond which would occur under Alternative 1. This would
accelerate further soil compaction and exposure to erosion in the riparian area and on the
stream banks, these effects are discussed in Sections 3.2.2.2 and 3.4.2.2 and mitigations
related to these effects are provided in Sections 3.2.4 and 3.4.4. The current site design has a
proposed grassy commons that terraces down to the south along the east side of the building.
